div.sent: We know that we need to apply force in order to do work.
But there are some techniques of applying forces so that work becomes easier to perform.
Some work that requires enough force can be done with minimum force if the proper technique is followed.
The technical devices that we use to do work with minimum force are called machines.
In this chapter we shall discuss some simple machines.
What is a simple machine?
What do you usually do to lift a heavy box from ground?
Which one is easier?
Definitely the later one.
In this case the work has been done by applying less force.
Only you have applied a trick by a using a rod.
Here, the rod is used as a simple machine, which has made the work done easily and by minimum efforts.
We use many such simple machines in our daily life, such as knife, scissor, pliers, crowbar, lever etc.
There are complex machines too, such as sewing machine, bi- cycle, tractor etc.
But whatever complex they are, they are only a combination of some simple machines.
Some simple machines increase the applied force and make the work easy.
The later example mentioned above shows how machines can be used to do work easily.
Here the force applied at one end of the rod has been multiplied at the other end.
Scissors, pliers, crowbar, wrench, screw etc. are examples of such machines.
There are machines, which can alter the direction of force.
The paddle of cycle is such a machine by which downward force is applied by feet on a paddle which makes the cycle go forward.
The national flag in your school is hoisted by a pulley.
Here the rope on one side of the pulley is drawn downward but the flag fixed on the other side goes up.
Again, there are machines which work to increase motion and distance.
To get a guava from the top of the tree you use a bamboo stick.
Here the bamboo stick is the simple machine.
By increasing distance it multiplies the motion of your hand.
A sweeper increases the motion of his hand by using a handle on his broom.
So we see that simple machines are appliances by which work can be done easily and without much effort.
These machines may work by increasing force, by altering direction of force or by increasing distance and motion.
Lever Simple machines like knife, Scissors, crowbar, wrench, broom etc are called levers.
Even our hands, legs, fingers work like levers.
By them we can move, shift or raise things and can apply force in many different ways.
When a crow bar is used to raise a heavy box, it acts as a lever.
Here the crowbar is supported by a stone or brick or something hard.
You apply small force on one end and get the force multiplied on the other end.
This is the principle that works behind the functioning of a lever.
Lever makes work easy to do and also increases the force.
So, a work that normally requires a great force, can be done easily with the help of a lever by applying a small force.
The principle behind the functioning of a lever can be understood from figure 9.
The lever is supported on a dot or line of a hard object.
The lever moves or rotates centering this dot or line.
This dot or line is called fulcrum of the lever.
The heavy object which is to be raised by a lever is called load and is kept at one end of the lever.
On the other end of the lever force is applied.
This means, the longer the force arm, the smaller the force to be applied to raise loads.
Say, force arm is three times longer than the load arm.
Then the load can be raised by applying a force three times greater.
That is, 9 times load can be raised by applying 1 time force.
If a load is 900 Newton it Can be raised by applying 100 Newton force.
A machine changes the applied force by a certain ratio.
Mechanical advantage is a number by which a machine changes the applied force.
Mechanical advantage may be more than 1, may be equal to 1, or less than 1.
Sometimes we lift less load by applying greater force for our convenience.
Here, the mechanical advantage is less than 1.
The fulcrum of the lever will not be always in between the load and the force.
It may be at one end too.
Depending on the position of fulcrum, load and force lever is classified in three categories class I lever, class II lever, Class III lever.
When fulcrum is in between the load and force the lever is called class I lever.
In this class of lever fulcrum and force are at the two ends and the load remains at the middle.
Nut cracker is an example of this class of lever.
Two parts of cracker is joined at a point, this point is the fulcrum.
Force is applied by hand at the other end point and load is exerted on the nut at the middle.
In this class of lever, force is applied to the middle in between load and fulcrum.
Example of such levers are tong or forceps.
Perhaps you have noticed an inclined plank when oildrums are loaded on a truck.
The loaded drum is rolled over the inclined plank to the truck (fig 9.4).
Why is it done like this?
This is because it is easier to role over on inclined plank than to raise things vertically.
So an inclined plank makes the job easier, Therefore it is the example of a simple machine.
This work is equal to the work done on the body raised vertically in distance.
The length of the inclined plain is greater than its height.
So to role a body over inclined plain the distance to be covered is great but the force is to be applied is small.
Say, the length of an inclined plain is 3 metres and its height is 1 metre.
From the relation above, 300 Newton load can be raised by a force of 100 Newton only.
So the work will be done easily.
Inclined plain is one of the simple machines that men learnt to use since the early phase of civilisation.
Examples of human application of inclined plains can be found in the stairs of a building, road to go upwards etc.
They are made inclined instead of vertical as it is much easier to climb up an inclined way when going upwards.
Pulley is a notched wheel which rotates freely on an axis.
You may have seen it in your school when flag is hoisted on a long stand.
A rope on a notched wheel can pull a heavy load tied at one end by pulling it toward the other end (fig 9.6).
Pulley does not increase force rather it changes the direction of force.
Force is applied downward at the end of the rope and the load tied on the other end goes upward.
Applied force is almost equal to the load which may be a bit larger to overcome friction.
But it is easier to raise a load by pulling it downward than to raise it vertically, straightway.
For this advantage pulley is used.
Wheel and axle is a machine in which a rod of smaller diameter is attached to a wheel of larger diameter.
A long rope is spiraled over the wheel and axle as shown in figure 9.
Force is applied at this end.
By applying small force, large load can be raised, wheel and axel not only increases force but also alters the direction of force.
This is an altered form of lever.
Here force arm is the diameter of the wheel and load arm is the diameter of the rod of the axle.
Wheel and axle is used to draw water from well.
Steering wheel of a car and screw driver are the modified forms of the wheel and axle.
You all might have seen screw drivers; some of you perhaps used them too.
Take two screw drivers, one with fat handle and the other with narrow handle.
Which one is easy to work with?
You will see that the one with fat handle is easier to work with.
The reason is that the screw driver is a modified form of wheel and axle.
Here, the handle works as wheel and the steel rod works as axle.
Therefore, the broader the handle is the easier it is to work with.
When a punctured wheel of a motor car is to be replaced by a spare wheel, the car needs to be raised from the ground.
The driver of the car do not raise it by applying manual force.
This can be easily done by a jack screw.
A jack screw is a fat screw made of steel.
There is a handle attached to it as shown in figure (9.8).
The upper part of the screw is either raised above or lowered down by rotating the handle.
A jack screw works at a time on the principles of lever and the inclined plane.
The spiral screw works as inclined plain as the screw spirals over from one end to the other.
The distance covered is the length of the inclined plane and the height of the spiral screw is the height of the inclined plane.
Thus by increasing the length of the inclined plane, much heavy load is raised by applying small force.
Also direction of force applied on the handle is perpendicular to the load.
So jack screw makes work easier by increasing the applied force as well as by changing the direction of force.
We use pumps in various work in our daily life.
In tubewell pump draws drinking water from below the earth surface.
We use pump to irrigate our crop fields.
With pump we raise water from reservoirs below to water tanks placed on the house roofs.
Pump is also used in pushing air in bicycle wheels and football bladders.
What actually does a pump do?
How does pumps work in the examples mentioned above?
Pumps simply take water or air i.e. liquid or gas from one place to another.
Liquid and gas have at least one property in common-they flow from places of higher pressure to that of lower one.
This property is used in operating pump.
We can say that machines which shift liquids and gases from one place to another by using air pressure is called pumps.
In the barrel an airtight piston moves up and down.
This is used to reduce the atmospheric pressure in the barrel.
A special kind of door is used to make liquid or gas flow in one direction only.
This door is called valve.
It has an one way opening only.
Fluids move in that direction but remain closed when it tries to move in the opposite direction.
Pump may be of various types.
We only discuss one type of pump here-lift pump.
This pump is used to raise water to a certain height.
The handle acts as lever.
There is a narrow pipe at the bottom of the barrel.
This pipe leads the pumpup to the water which is to be raised.
On the upper side of the barrel there is a pipe, through which water can go out.
The pump has two valves.
V1 is at the junction of the barrel and narrow pipe.
The other V2 is attached to the piston.
Both the valves open in upward directions only.
The piston is lowered and the volume between valves V1 and V2 decreases as such the pressure increases.
The increase of pressure opens valve V2 but closes valve V1.
A certain amount of air goes out through VNow, as the piston is drawn upward, the air pressure decreases.
Thus valve V1 opens and some quantity of air from the narrow pipe enters into the barrel.
As a result air pressure decreases into the tube.
So due to atmospheric pressure on the surface of water, some quantity of water comes through the barrel from the tube through V1.
Again when the piston is lowered, V1 opens and V2 remains closed.
The Water which entered before in the barrel now goes above the piston.
The piston was drawn upward; the water which was collected above the piston now goes out through the pipe.
At the same time V1 opens again, valve V2 being closed, atmospheric pressure forces some water to the barrel through V1.
Only when the handle is lowered, the piston moves up and water goes to the delivery pipe.
In lift pump water enters barrel through V1 by an atmospheric pressure.
Normal atmospheric pressure can support 76 cm.
height of mercury column which is equal to 10.3 m water column.
In tubewell lift pump is used.
Tubewell is used to get drinking water and it is also used for irigation of lands.
